awd_titl_txt: DEB Proposal: SG: Collaborative Research: Repeated evolution of limblessness and head-first burrowing in tetrapods: Testing predictions from the fossil record
awd_abstract_narration:
Animal species have evolved an incredible diversity of body shapes to reflect their different ecology and functions, e.g., swimming, flying, burrowing. An intriguing pattern is the independent evolutionary repetition of similar body shapes among distantly related groups of animal species; this is known as convergent evolution. How and why convergence of body shape occurs is a fundamental evolutionary puzzle. This research project examines the anatomical, biomechanical, developmental, and natural selection pressures that drive the evolution of limblessness and head-first burrowing. Burrowing behavior and the loss of limbs is a classic case of convergent evolution, and this project will test general hypotheses concerning the selective pressures that gave give rise to similar body shapes in various snakes, lizard and amphibian species. In this project, computer analysis will be applied to images of skull shape created with technologies derived from medical imaging. That data will then be used to test for relationships between form and function in both fossils and living animals. The results of this work will be important to understanding how and why evolution arrived repeatedly at some common biomechanical solutions for burrowing. The proposed research also provides unique mentoring and outreach opportunities. This project will provide research experience for students from underserved communities. It will develop a mobile toolkit of both analog and digital components devoted to science outreach activities, and it will inform the public about evolutionary processes through multiple public outreach events. 

The research project will test for variation in the causes of head-first burrowing (HFB) which is a prominent example of convergent evolution. Reduction and loss of limbs is associated with the use of the head as a burrowing tool across snakes, amphibians, multiple clades of lizards, and several extinct tetrapod groups. The research will describe and quantify the morphological variability in bony and soft tissues in living HFB species. Micro CT and histological data will be collected to assess biomaterial composition, suture patterns, and developmental trajectories across distantly-related taxa. Those results will be placed in a phylogenetic and developmental context using phylogenetic comparative methods. The work will thus infer form, function, and evolutionary history from the patterns of variability. The investigative framework devised for extant taxa will then be applied to extinct, putative HFB taxa to provide independent tests of prior observational hypotheses made for fossils. The reach of this work will be extended through data sharing of the 3D anatomical models, phylogenetic matrices, and specimen data via NSF-supported databases such as Morphobank and Dryad.

por.por_cntn:
Similarities in body plan shape, such as wings in birds and bats, and the evolutionary steps to achieve those shapes, represent convergent evolution. This overall similarity may be attributed to shared external factors like shared environments or diets, or it may be linked to intrinsic factors like evolutionary history or shared developmental pathways. We examined convergent evolution in the body plans of head-first burrowing (HFB) tetrapods. This behavior evolved multiple times independently across caecilian amphibians and many squamates (e.g. snakes, amphisbaenian lizards, geckos), as well as in many extinct tetrapods.

A crucial part of our work describes individual variation, an understudied and underappreciated phenomenon. We tend to view species or populations as having set characteristics that are consistent across all members. However, that perspective overlooks the differences across individuals that are the actual starting points for adaptive evolution. We assessed individual variation in skull shape and bone connections in the amphisbaenian Diplometopon, a charismatic limbless lizard. By analyzing 3D models from CT data, we recognized differences in the number and location of small openings in the skulls, how tightly and complexly connected bones were to each other, and the proportions of bones (Figure 1). We also noted variation between the left and right sides of individuals. Individual differences could be the result of ontogeny (variation from growth stages), but also may exist as acceptable levels of variation with respect to HFB performance. We are currently applying finite element analysis (FEA) to specimens from this same sample of Diplometopon to understand how variation affects the distribution of stress and strain across the skull. So far, the highest strain has been found around the occipital condyles, which may relate to how force is transmitted from the front of the skull down the vertebral column during burrowing.

From there we looked at the next level of organization, investigating differences in skull shape across a whole collection of closely related species. We focused on another unusual and highly limb-reduced lizard group, the pygopodids or ‘flap-footed’ geckos. Unlike more acrobatic geckos, pygopodids move through small crevices and burrow underground, while also possessing absurdly pointed (Lialis) or shortened heads (Aprasia), depending on their specialized diets (Figure 2). Using 3D geometric morphometrics to mathematically compare shapes, we found that habitat correlated significantly with shape differences in skulls. The two subterranean genera Aprasia and Ophidiocephalus had some of the most distinct and overlapping skull shapes, but in each case different bones contributed to the similar shape. This suggested that each genus adapted to living underground in a slightly different way, demonstrating convergence even within this small group. 

Those results emphasized the importance of shape differences as they relate to ecology, but another overlooked aspect of building a skull that is used as a digging tool is the structure of the bone itself. To explore differences in microanatomy we teamed up with international collaborators to measure differences in the thickness and compactness of skull roofing bones across amphibians. We were interested in whether variation would be correlated with different ecologies, such as living underground, in water, or even in trees. Based on prior work demonstrating that lizards and snakes that burrow have thicker, more compact bone in the front of their skulls, we were surprised to find that salamanders, our best-studied amphibian group, lacked that association. The salamanders we surveyed had bone that was more than 97% compact, and the strongest association was found with an aquatic rather than subterranean ecology. Most salamanders are relatively small, so perhaps there is simply no room for spaces within bone. We look forward to further exploring that surprising result in our ongoing study of frogs, a group with a wider taxonomic diversity and size range, and caecilians, which actively HFB. 

Finally, we applied what we learned to interpreting fossils of potential HFBs. We focused on the fossil record of caecilian amphibians which today are fully limbless, fossorial, and restricted to equatorial regions. Their fossil record should go back more than 250 million years based on molecular data; however, only 11 fossils were known. We focused new fieldwork on the Triassic Period, a time of diversification of many living lineages. From our sampling and screenwashing at fossil sites within Petrified Forest National Park (Arizona), we were able to identify the first Late Triassic fossils of caecilians. Based on lower jaw elements, more than 76 individuals were preserved, in addition to other parts of the skull and postcrania. This new caecilian, Funcusvermis gilmorei, helps us understand the timing and sequence of the evolution of a HFB body plan in this group, It also suggests that features like a tubular trunk appeared before changes to the jaws or loss of the limbs, and that evaporative water loss might be a limiting factor restricting caecilians to the tropics.
